data.text: Contents
Introduction
In order to co-ordinate Trust-wide collaboration, this document sets out appropriate procedures to be followed whilst Very Important Persons (VIP) are receiving healthcare within the Trust.

These procedures also advise of the appropriate protocol to be followed in the arrangement and management of visits to the Trust by VIPs and guests including royalty, government minsters, celebrities and dignitaries from home or abroad and other significant members of the community.
Scope

The purpose of this document is to: sets out the general principles and framework for the admission criteria and care of patients who are categorised as Very Important People (VIP), and the management of VIP visits to the Trust
There are two categories of VIP described in this document for emergency admissions:
Category One: Principal VIP (royal family)
Category Two: Other VIP
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee
4.1.1  The Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee is responsible for ensuring that plans are in place to:
Supporting the development and implementation of Emergency Planning and Resilience capabilities in preparation for an emergency situation
Ensuring a Business Impact Analysis is completed for their Care Group / Division and specific service areas as deemed necessary
Ensuring a Directorate Resilience Plan (including Emergency Planning and Business Continuity) is in place for their Care Group / Division, if required.
Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the MSE has in place effective arrangements to respond to an incident that has the potential to affect service provision
Deputy Chief Executive / Accountable Emergency Officer (AEO)

4.3.1 The Deputy Chief Executive is the designated Accountable Emergency Officer for Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response, who is responsible for ensuring that the MSE has a Major Incident Plan in place that will also link into the organisations arrangements for business continuity, that is built on the principles of risk assessment, co-operation with partners, emergency planning, communicating with the public and information sharing.

4.3.2 The role of the AEO, is to endorse assurance to the board that the organisation is meeting its obligations with respect to EPRR and relevant statutory obligations under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA) and the Health and Social Care Act 2012. This will include assurance that the organisation has allocated appropriate resources to meet the requirements.

4.3.3 The AEO will ensure that the Board receives regular reports, at least annually, regarding EPRR including reports on exercises, training and testing undertaken by the Trust, and that appropriate resources are made available to allow the discharge of these responsibilities.
Director of Operations (Local Services) are responsible for ensuring that:
Business Continuity plans are developed and in place for their areas and functions of responsibility.
Business Continuity plans are cascaded to staff who are given appropriate training.
Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response will review the actions taken to ensure they have been understood and followed once the plan has been initiated in a response.
General Managers
Oversee the effective implementation of the plan within their Divisions.
Ensure ward managers and heads of department have effective plans in place to manage staffing and activity during a fuel shortage in line with their business continuity plans.
Representation on the Fuel Incident Team
Head of Communications
Ensuring there is an effective cascade system for informing staff that there is disruption to fuel supplies and what the contingency measures are
Developing agreed pre-prepared information for the intranet (Hub) and website on mitigating procedures, responsible purchasing of fuel, fuel efficiency measures, staff safety etc.
Co-ordinate media correspondence.
Co-ordinate communications to trust staff.
Representation on the Fuel Incident Team
Estates and Facilities Manager
Will organise on request from the Fuel Incident Team accommodation for key staff during a disruption
Will maintain information on local accommodation that may be accessed by the Trust if required
Representation on the Fuel Incident Team
Service Unit Managers / Ward Managers / Heads of Departments
Ensure staff are aware of their responsibilities.
Manage flexibility within shift patterns and consider reducing the number of shifts worked (by increasing hours each shift).
Team leaders for inpatient units to consider early discharge to cater for possible reduced levels of staff.
Ensure arrangements are in place for maintaining continuity of services.
Implement action plans agreed by Emergency Planning Panel where relevant.
Identify staff who may work either at home or closer to home.
Brief staff of the situation, any new developments and Trust actions.
Local Security Manager
The Trust security management service will maintain a presents on the main hospital site at all times.
All staff within the Trust security management service will have received enhanced security clearance from the Criminal Records Bureau / Disclosure and Barring Service.

All staff within the Trust security management service will receive appropriate training in security procedures as to provide the Trust staff, patients and visitors with an efficient and effective security management service.
All security management service staff will be supplied with the appropriate personal protective clothing.
In the event of absenteeism or additional security management service personnel, an external agency may be used from the nominated list ensuring that the supplied personnel are registered and legal.
Staff
Prioritise journeys, avoiding unnecessary journeys and taking into consideration fuel needed to attend work.
Utilise other means of transport where possible such as public transport, car sharing, walking or cycling to work.
Where the staff member had inadequate fuel to make the journey to work they should make every attempt to attend work by other means.
If all means have been exhausted and the staff member is unable to attend work
they should contact their line manager giving as much notice as possible before the planned shift.
Procedure
Definitions of a VIP fall into two categories in this document for emergency admission. These are:
5.1.1 VIPs – include but not restricted to MPs, Ministers, elected representatives, overseas dignitaries, and members of the royal Family.
5.1.2 Celebrities – famous/high profile figures that might be well known to the public, patients and their families, also including costumed as these would be well known to children and young people.
Notification

table_items.text: The Lead Physician to the Principal or the Personal Protection Officer will notify the specialist / on-call consultant or the on-call director via switchboard. The specialist / on-call consultant will alert the on-call director via switchboard, who will then alert the chief executive and convene a Hospital Control Team if required. Membership would consist of: Managing Director Site Operations Director Site medical Director Site Director of Nursing Head of Communications Head of EPRR or EPRR Manager Clinical Director for the speciality Divisional General Manager for the speciality Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) Head of Portering

Depending on the referral route, the receiving consultant will notify the on- call director via switchboard, who will then notify the chief executive and convene a Hospital Control Team if required. Membership would consist of: Managing Director Site Operations Director Site medical Director Site Director of Nursing Head of Communications Head of or Manager of EPRR Clinical Director for the speciality Divisional General Manager for the speciality Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) Heads of Portering

data.text: Secure admission process

table_items.text: Registration on Arrival: On arrival the Principal should be afforded a pseudonym. Sets of notes containing the alias and hospital number should be kept separately and secured. Out of Hours: Electronic notes/images should only be made in a secure area of the relevant programme i.e. EMR Patient Accommodation: If the Principal requires acute cardiovascular intervention or other cardiovascular intervention, the Principle should be admitted to a side room on Brook Suite in the CTC (Basildon Site). If an ICU pathway is required, move to: Colne ward as a first priority. What about other intervention? Security: Lockdown procedures for the receiving ward should be instigated where required, in liaison with the security team in attendance. Royal Staff and Security: Accommodation will need to be identified for the Royal Physician(s).

Registration on Arrival: Routine admission procedure will be followed unless deviations are requested by any security support. Patient Accommodation: Need to explain here what would happen as standard Basildon Hospital If an ICU pathway is required, use Colne Ward as a first priority. Broomfield Hospital If an ICU pathway is required Designated side room ICU HDU Follow HDU pathway Southend Hospital If an ICU pathway is required Designated side room ICU HDU Follow HDU pathway VIPs who wish to move to the private patient facility at a point in care should discuss with their consultant, who will then activate the appropriate procedures via the director on-call.

data.text: Transportation

table_items.text: a) Emergency Vehicle - PPCI Entrance. b) Private Vehicle - PPCI Entrance. c) Helicopter - Basildon Gold Course Once disembarked all vehicles should be parked in the CTC Car Park
a) Emergency Vehicle - PPCI Entrance. b) Private Vehicle - PPCI Entrance. c) Helicopter - Basildon Gold Course Once disembarked all vehicles should be parked in the CTC Car Park

data.text: Security

table_items.text: A Principal VIP will provide his/her own security, including the Police. Liaison with the Trust LSMS and portering and transport service manager is essential at the earliest opportunity. Maps and other relevant plans will need to be provided for the security team. Lockdown may be required at the relevant ward. Secure storage will need to be supplied for patient notes. Extra support for car parking and security staff may need to be considered. Communication on radio frequencies and mobile phones is to be kept to a minimum. The CCTV coverage may need to be restricted. Swipe card access may need to be afforded to the security staff of the Principal and Royal Physician(s). Staff should be reminded at the earliest opportunity to ensure they carry their ID badges with then at all times and not

Where a VIP has provided their own security, liaison with the Trust LSMS and portering and transport service manager is essential at the earliest opportunity. Maps and other relevant plans will need to be provided dependant of the security risk of the VIP at the earliest opportunity. Police will be notified as appropriate. Lockdown may be required at the relevant ward. Secure storage will need to be supplied for patient notes. Communication on radio frequencies and mobile phones is to be kept to a minimum. The CCTV coverage may need to be restricted. Dependant on the level of security required for the VIP, swipe card access may need to be afforded to the security staff of the VIP. Staff should be reminded at the earliest opportunity to ensure they carry their ID badges with then at all times and not

to discuss the presence of the Principal outside of work. Ward Sisters will be asked to prepare an on-going list of inpatient names and scheduled visitors (within confidentiality guidelines) to be verified by the security liaison team.
to discuss the presence of the VIP outside of work. Ward Sisters may be asked to prepare an on-going list of inpatient names and scheduled visitors to be verified by designated individual.

data.text: Communications

table_items.text: Outside lines may need to be restricted with access controlled via the switchboard. A secure outside line will need to be afforded to the Principal VIP. Mobiles and pagers may need to be loaned from the switchboard manager. Radios may need to be loaned from the security office or Emergency Planning Officer (an emergency channel should be made available). The Porters and Estates personnel should be reminded to restrict all radio transmissions to an operational minimum. Staff working within the vicinity where the Category 1 principle VIP is being treated, should be reminded not to use their mobiles at work until stand down is given. In order to maintain command and control, all non-clinical decisions must only come from the director on-call.

Outside lines may need to be restricted with access controlled via the switchboard. Dependant on the level of security required for the VIP a secure outside line may need to be afforded to the patient. Mobiles and pagers may need to be loaned from the switchboard manager. Radios may need to be loaned from the security office or Emergency Planning Officer (an emergency channel should be made available). The Porters and Estates personnel should be reminded to restrict all radio transmissions to an operational minimum. Staff working within the vicinity where they should be reminded not to use their mobiles at work until stand down is given. In order to maintain command and control, all non-clinical decisions must only come from the Director or Senior Manager on-call.

data.text: Media

table_items.text: All Trust staff should be reminded at the earliest opportunity not to talk to the media or persons unknown. The Trusts communications team will liaise with the Principal's press representatives. Press releases should be agreed in advance with the Principal's press representative. Press releases will be managed by the Trust's, communications team under guidance with the principal's press representatives and the chief executive or director on-call. The Trusts Communications team may need to liaise with the CCG and/or NHS England dependant on the nature of the situation. The communications team will liaise with the senior manager for the areas and manage the distribution of information to staff on a daily basis. The communications team would manage the media, providing an appropriate location off-site and provide them with regular updates.

All Trust staff should be reminded at the earliest opportunity not to talk to the media or persons unknown. The Trusts communications team will liaise with the VIP press representatives. Press releases will be managed by the Trust's communications team in conjunction with the Incident Control team. The communications team may need to liaise with the CCG and/or NHS England dependant on the nature of the situation. The communications team will liaise with the senior manager for the areas and manage the distribution of information to staff on a daily basis. The communications team would manage the media, providing an appropriate location off-site and them with regular updates. .

data.text: Discharge

table_items.text: On discharge, documentation and correspondence will be given to the Royal Physician where appropriate. Any clinical notes which need to remain at the Trust for further use will be secured in a safe haven, the location of which can be identified through the executive team via the Chief Executive or On-call Director. All electronic notes/images should be secured in the relevant safe haven of the software. Any backup should be disposed of, or transferred to the safe
The usual discharge process will be followed unless there are any specific requests depending on the VIP.

haven of the software or CD/memory stick at the earliest opportunity. The discharge should be carefully managed with the attending physician and security team. CCTV footage may need to be quarantined or run out through its due course. Stand down will only be given by the Director or Senior Manager on-call and only once the Principal VIP has left the Trust and the liaison teams have agreed it is safe to do so. A debrief will be held at the earliest opportunity following stand down to ensure that any learning is captured and this procedure updated.

data.text: Staff

Only permanent staff will be allocated responsibility for the care and security of VIPs. These will normally be identified by the management team and will not include any unknown temporary or agency staff.
Gifts

Gifts for a VIP can constitute a major problem for the Trust, from a standpoint volume alone. There is also a very high security risk. A method of dealing with gifts for VIP will need to be discussed with the relevant authorities at the earliest opportunity. Some VIP patients will offer gifts to staff. Staff should be reminded about the protocols following the offer of a gift from a patient or relative.
Language, culture and special requests
The general principle governing special requests is to be prepared to grant reasonable ones, but to ask ahead of time for some idea of what special-needs requests may be required.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring

Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Review of procedure following its instigation and use

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies, plans and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Document Control Manager of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 2: VIP liaison manager
Role: To liaise with the Principle Protection Officer and other organisation as required
in the event that VIPs are involved in the incident.
Tasks
In the event of VIPs being involved, to make contact with the Principle Protection
Officer regarding the treatment and deployment of the VIP Protection Team.
To liaise with external organisations in relation to the safety and protection of the
VIP.
To liaise with other healthcare organisations in the event that the VIP is
transferred out of the hospital.
To keep the Chief Executive informed of all VIP casualties and their status.
Appendix 3: VIP visit – brief guide for staff

There are occasions when a VIP might visit one of our hospitals or a Trust service. VIPs include members of the Royal family, senior politicians (e.g. Secretary of State, Ministers), local MPs (or prospective MPs), formal visit from an eminent clinician, celebrities, sportspeople etc.
This brief guidance aims to ensure that staff follow correct procedures around arranging, planning and hosting VIP visits.
Getting agreement for a VIP visit

Before inviting a VIP to visit the Trust (or if you have been approached, before agreeing to a VIP visit) you must first get agreement from your line manager, clinical director, general manager, head of nursing and Director of Operations.

Before agreeing to the visit, the proposed arrangements must also be discussed with the communications department, to ensure the visit does not clash with any other Trust event. Agreement will also be sought from the Chief Executive and Chairman.
This is important because many formal approaches to ask VIPs to the Trust must come from the Trust Chairman.
Planning a VIP visit

Once a visit has been agreed, the service being visited will work with the communications department to arrange the visit. The communications department is able to advise on drafting a programme, discussing arrangements for the visit, arranging photographs and media activity etc.
During a VIP visit

Immediately before the VIP visit, the visit host should ensure staff, patients and visitors know that there is going to be a visit to their area, what the arrangements are for the visit, and gain consent from staff and patients for photos to be taken.

During the VIP visit, the VIP will usually be accompanied by the Chief Executive. The service being visited should identify a chaperone to escort them. The communications department will manage any attending media.
Following a VIP visit
The communications department will send out a press release (if appropriate) and monitor the media for any coverage.
If you have any queries about VIP visits, please contact the communications department
